listBibl.bibl: Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). Pagan Love: Murray Gibbon’s New Novel. The Morning Albertan, December 2, 1922, p. 4.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). News, Notes and Views About Books [Review of Grant Overton’s When Winter Comes to Main Street]. The Morning Albertan, December 11, 1922, p. 4.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). News, Notes and Views about Books [Calgary Authors]. The Morning Albertan, December 14, 1922, p. 4.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). News, Notes and Views About Books. The Morning Albertan, December 16, 1922, pp. 4, 17.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). Books [Review of Arthur Stringer’s The Prairie Child]. The Morning Albertan, December 22, 1922, p. 10.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). News, Notes and Views about Books [Review of George C. F. Pringle’s Tillicums of the Trail]. The Morning Albertan, December 30, 1922, pp. 4, 18.

Canadian Authors Needed to Give True Idea of Resources. The Morning Albertan, January 18, 1923, p. 7.[BLURB? Not written directly by WE, but it seems to be a long quotation — very similar to other things like Canadian Spirit]
Reeve, Winnifred. Books by Winnifred Reeve [The Kaiser’s Memoirs]. The Morning Albertan, January 29, 1923, p. 4, 14.

Canada Libelled by Authors from Alien Countries. The Morning Albertan, February 15, 1923, p. 3.[BLURB? This one is explicitly signed as quotations, but each paragraph is a quotation that ends with said Mrs. Reev.]

Watanna, Onota. Carnival Spirit in Full Swing at Banff; Lack of Snow no Deterrent to Fun. The Morning Albertan, March 3, 1923, p. 7.[An odd piece of reporting…but was Written Specially for The Morning Albertan by Onota Watann.]

Watanna, Onoto. Banff Masked Ball Is Fun Festival; Carnival Ends With Crowning of Queen. The Morning Albertan, March 6, 1923, p. 7. [Another odd piece written specially. — spelling of name also fixed — definitely something SL would be interested given the costumed parade of war dancing.]
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). Books and Literary Notes. The Morning Albertan, March 26, 1923, p. 2.[About children’s book with Calgary connections]
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). Books and Current Literary Matters. The Morning Albertan, March 28, 1923, pp. 4, 10.
Watanna, Onoto. Books by Onoto Watanna: Canadian Cities of Romance by Katharine Hale. The Morning Albertan, July 9, 1923, pp. 4, 13.[The series shifts in name and Eaton goes solely by Watanna here].

Reeve, Winnifred. Books [The Bond Triumphant, part 1]. The Morning Albertan, August 7, 1923, p. 4.[Also condemns Maclean’s, a Canadian publication, for giving first prize to an American novel, Thoroughbred]
Reeve, Winnifred. Books by Winnifred Reeve [Review of The Bond Triumphant]. The Morning Albertan, October 5, 1923, p. 4.
Reeve, Winnifred. Literary Notes [Hale]. The Morning Albertan, October 9, 1923, pp. 4, 12.
Eaton Reeve, Winnifred. Books, Literary Notes, Etc. The Morning Albertan, November 13, 1923, pp. 4, 18.[Begins to talk about Bookweek and Salverson]
Reeve, Winnifred (Onota Watanna). Canadian Authors (Mrs. Laura Goodman Salversen). The Morning Albertan, November 19, 1923, pp. 6, 14.
What Canadians Have Achieved in Literature. The Morning Albertan, November 24, 1923, p. 8. [BLURB? — Mostly reported speech from WE in role as CAA Pres. Discusses animal stories.]
Reeve, Winnifred. Literature as a Business Proposition. The Morning Albertan, November 26, 1923, pp. 4, 14.[Full version of Literature as a Profession. I think — but also great]

Eaton Reeve, Winnifred. Books. The Morning Albertan, February 5, 1924, p. 4.[Discusses/critiques new short stories by American authors writing about Canada; urges readers to see Bliss Carman, Canada’s poet laureate, in upcoming visit]
Eaton Reeve, Winnifred. Books, Literary Notes, Etc. The Morning Albertan, April 4, 1924, p. 4.
Reeve, Winnifred (Onoto Watanna). Wilson Macdonald. The Morning Albertan, April 5, 1924, p. 7.

Eaton Reeve, Winnifred. The Canadian Authors’ Association. The Calgary Albertan, May 22, 1924, pp. 4, 16.[This one is really fascinating — she’s ousted just a week or two earlier due to the Salverson scandal, more-or-less]
